description: Olmstead v. United States - telephone wiretapping without physical intrusion
facts: Federal agents tapped telephone lines without warrant
Taps installed on wires outside defendants' premises
No physical entry into homes or offices occurred
Conversations recorded and used as evidence
asp_facts: case(olmstead). amendment(olmstead, fourth). surveillance_type(olmstead, wiretap). physical_intrusion(olmstead, no). location(olmstead, outside_premises). warrant_obtained(olmstead, no). conversations_intercepted(olmstead, yes). duration(olmstead, months). physical_trespass(olmstead, no).
question: Does wiretapping telephone conversations without physical trespass violate the Fourth Amendment?
rationale: The Fourth Amendment protects material things only - persons, houses, papers, and effects. Since there was no physical trespass into a constitutionally protected area, and conversations are not tangible things that can be seized, the wiretapping did not violate the Fourth Amendment. (Note: This decision was later overruled by Katz v. United States)
